feed.title: Over Half of Replace-by-Fee-Rate Replacements Are Mined

entry.title: Over Half of Replace-by-Fee-Rate Replacements Are Mined
entry.summary:
The discussion revolves around the intricacies of the Libre Relay implementation, particularly focusing on its unique handling of feerates for transactions. Unlike traditional systems that rely heavily on mempool conditions to set limits, Libre Relay adopts a memoryless approach, allowing for Replace-By-Fee (RBF) transactions to surpass the expected next block feerate. This functionality, while advantageous in ensuring transaction confirmations, could potentially lead to excessive expenditure if used to consistently beat the next block's feerate, especially when considering the historical range of feerates from 1 satoshi per virtual byte (sat/vB) to less than 1000 sat/vB. The analysis suggests that employing such a strategy for fee elevation might not be economically rational compared to other forms of network attacks, such as Direct Denial of Service (DoS) against public nodes, which could offer a similar level of disruption at a potentially lower cost.
Further examination into the technical developments reveals an absence of a specific patch in the version 26.0 codebase that addresses this issue, with uncertainty surrounding its inclusion in the forthcoming v26.1 update. However, the possibility of manually integrating this patch is highlighted as a straightforward solution to mitigate any potential challenges arising from this oversight. For more detailed insights into the feasibility and implications of Replace-By-Fee and denial-of-service attacks within this context, the referenced work by Peter Todd offers an extensive analysis, accessible through [this link](https://petertodd.org/2024/one-shot-replace-by-fee-ratedenial-of-service-attacks). Additionally, communication channels remain open for further discussion and updates on this subject, as indicated by the provided contact information.
